Fig. 1 Experimental setup for epoxidation of α-pinene. Fig 1 Fig. 2 The influence of solvent type (a), solvent dosage (b), Mn loading amount (c), air flow rate (d), reaction temperature (e), reaction time (f), catalyst amount (g), and co-reductant amount (h) on epoxidation of α-pinene over Mn-SAPO-34. reaction conditions: α-pinene (1.0 g), acetonitrile (20 g), Mn loading amount (3 wt%), air flow rate (70 mL/min), 12 °C, 3 h, catalyst amount (120 mg) and co-reductant amount (0.8 g). Fig 2 Fig. 3 Diagnostic plots of optimization process: predicated vs actual value for 2,3-epoxy-pinane yield model. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Response surface plot (a) and contour lines diagram (b) of the effect of co-reductant amount and Mn loading amount on the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Response surface plots (a) and contour lines diagram (b) of the effect of co-reductant and catalyst amount on the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Response surface plots (a) and contour lines diagram (b) of the effect of Mn loading amount and catalyst amount on the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Reusability investigation of Mn-SAPO-34 in the epoxidation of α-pinene. Fig 7 Fig. 8 XRD patterns of Mn-SAPO-34 (fresh) (a), Mn-SAPO-34 (1st) (b), Mn-SAPO-34 (2nd) (c), Mn-SAPO-34 (3rd) (d), Mn-SAPO-34 (4th) (e), Mn-SAPO-34 (5th) (f), Mn-SAPO-34 (6th) (g), Mn-SAPO-34 (7th) (h), Mn-SAPO-34 (8th) (i) and SAPO-34 (pure) (j). Aerobic epoxidation of bio-based olefins is an important topic in green and sustainable chemistry. In this work, an Mn/SAPO-34 catalyst was prepared by ion-exchange method for the epoxidation of α-pinene in presence of molecular oxygen and iso-butyraldehyde. The factors influencing α-pinene epoxidation were determined and the conditions were optimized by response surface methodology (RSM). The result showed that the sensitive conditions were co-reductant amount, Mn loading amount and catalyst amount. After optimization, α-pinene was completely converted and a 90.47% yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane was obtained. The result showed that the catalyst was reusable for six cycles. In addition, the support and catalysts were characterized by XRD, BET, ICP-OES, SEM-EDS, TEM and XPS, and it was confirmed the reasons for the degradation of the catalyst activity were the damage of crystal particles, the decrease in specific surface area of catalyst, the loss of active components and the irreversible oxidation of Mn2+ Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords α-Pinene Aerobic epoxidation Response surface methodology Mn-SAPO-34 catalyst Data availability The authors are unable or have chosen not to specify which data has been used. 1 Introduction Aerobic epoxidation of bio-based olefins has attracted tremendous interest in the fine chemicals and pharmaceutical industries, as epoxides are essential intermediates in the production of oxygenated natural and non-natural compounds [1–3]. α-pinene is a popular renewable bio-based olefin derived from rectified component turpentine oil of pine trees, which has attracted much attention in recent years [4]. Aerobic epoxidation of α-pinene can produce valuable fine chemicals, including verbenone, verbenol, and 2,3-epoxy-pinane. As an important epoxide, 2,3-epoxy-pinane can be used for the preparation of campholenic aldehyde, trans-carveol, isopinocamphone, and sobrerol [5,6]. These products are key components in the fields of biopharmaceutical, flavor and fragrance. Therefore, the benign and efficient synthesis of 2,3-epoxy-pinane by aerobic epoxidation of α-pinene is very critical. Traditionally, 2,3-epoxy-pinane is produced by the epoxidation of α-pinene with stoichiometric amount of peracid as oxidant, which is poisonous, hazardous and environmentally undesirable [7]. To overcome this drawback, several researchers have been devoted to the epoxidation of α-pinene with oxidants such as TBHP, H2O2, NaIO4, and O2 [8,9]. Among them, TBHP and H2O2 have the disadvantages of being expensive and excessive by-products generated, while molecular oxygen is the most favored oxidant due to its advantage of being cheap, environmentally friendly and easily available. However, in most cases, the epoxidation of α-pinene with oxygen is usually limited by extreme reaction conditions, and some by-products are formed resulting in a decreased yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane since the epoxidation occurs through an uncontrolled free radical mechanism [10–12]. It has been reported that high yields of epoxy products can be obtained by catalytic epoxidation systems in the presence of aldehyde which is used here as a co-reductant for the reduction of activated oxygen [13]. Mukaiyama et al. investigated the epoxidation of olefins to epoxides with high yields and selectivity in the co-existence of O2/aldehyde and metal catalysts inclusive of Ni, Co, Mn, and Fe with variable valence [14,15]. However, these catalysts are usually homogeneous transition metal complexes and are limited in large-scale applications due to lack of stability, and the homogeneous nature of the reaction so that separation of the products is difficult [16]. Thus, to overcome this disadvantage, recent research effort has concentrated on the preparation of efficient heterogeneous catalyst. Immobilization of transition metal complexes on solid supports is one of the effective ways to prepare heterogeneous catalysts. Nodzewska and Yan et al reviewed the catalytic applications of immobilized transition metal complexes in detail over the past two decades [17,18]. Many solid supports, including carbon nanotubes, molecular sieves, metal-organic frameworks (MOF), and graphene, have been reported to be used to anchor transition metal complexes [19–21]. However, the leaching of active species during the reaction and the low selectivity of epoxides in the product are still the real challenges at present, so there is an urgent need for us to develop more efficient heterogeneous catalysts for aerobic epoxidation. Recent relevant works suggest that Mn species appear to be required to enhance olefins epoxidation reaction. The generation of intermediates of high-spin Mn4+-oxo species is the reason for the high catalytic activity of Mn-based heterogeneous catalysts, which facilitate oxygen atom transfer and promote the formation of epoxides from olefins [22]. Chatterjee and co-workers propose a new synthetic approach by incorporating Mn into porous nanomaterials via framework substitution to produce Mn-APO-5 catalyst [23]. Recently, Pang et al. prepared an Mn-SAPO-11 catalyst by impregnating the support with NH4Cl solution and then replacing NH4+ with Mn solution instead of a one-step synthesis of Mn-based catalyst [24]. These techniques have been shown to generate efficient solid catalysts for the epoxidation of olefins in the presence of oxygen [25]. CHA topological SAPO-34 molecular sieve has received much interest in catalysis fields due to its high specific surface area and good hydrothermal stability. In addition, SAPO-34 has an interconnected three-dimensional pore network and super cages which are equivalent to independent reactors to facilitate the reaction of substrates without immediate clogging of pores [26]. In this work, an Mn-SAPO-34 catalyst was synthesized by ion-exchange method with SAPO-34 molecular sieve as a support and manganese acetate as the active component for the epoxidation of α-pinene. The effects of different reaction conditions on the conversion and yield were explored, and the sensitive factors were optimized by response surface method (RSM) to get high yields of 2,3-epoxy-pinane in the presence of O2 and iso-butyraldehyde. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time that Mn-SAPO-34 catalyst has been used for the epoxidation of α-pinene. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials α-Pinene was purchased from Chuxiong Hong Bang Industry & Trade Co., Ltd., iso-butyraldehyde was purchased from Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., and the other chemicals were purchased from Guangdong Guanghua Technology Co., Ltd and used without further purification. All chemicals were analytical grade without further treatment. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts SAPO-34 support was prepared by hydrothermal method [27]. The synthesis gel molar composition was Al2O3: SiO2: P2O5: triethylamine: H2O = 1: 0.6: 1: 3: 50. The sources of Al, Si and P were Pseudo-boehmite, silica sol and phosphoric acid, respectively. The pseudo-boehmite was mixed with H2O, and subsequently phosphoric acid, silica sol and diethylamine were added to the gel. The gel was transferred to a closed Teflon bottle at 200 °C for 48 h under static conditions. The solid product was filtered, washed and dried at 120 °C for 5 h, and followed by calcination in air atmosphere at 500 °C for 5 h with a heating rate of 1 °C/min to obtain SAPO-34 support. Mn-SAPO-34 catalyst was prepared by two-step ion-exchange method, as described in the literature [24]. First, the H-SAPO-34 was converted to NH4-SAPO-34 by ion exchange with NH4NO3 solution at 80 °C for 2 h. Then the material was filtered and washed with deionized water. Mn ion-exchange was performed by mixing NH4-SAPO-34 with Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O solution at 90 °C for 6 h. then it was filtration, washed with deionized water, and followed by drying at 110 °C for 6 h in an oven and finally Mn-SAPO-34 catalyst was obtained by calcined at 550 °C for 4 h. The Mn loading in the catalyst was expected to be 3 wt%. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a diffractometer (Rigaku, D/max-2200) with Cu Ka radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) from 2θ = 5° to 90° with a scan speed of 5°/min. Textural properties were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K using a Quantachrome Nova 4200e instrument, and specific surface area and average pore size were determined by the BET method and BJH method, respectively. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) was conducted on an instrument (Leeman, PROFILE SPEC) to analyze the contents of Mn, Al, Si, and P in samples. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX) point-scan analysis was obtained on a Nova Nanosem scanning electron microscope at 200 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken by using a Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN. The chemical valence states and elements present in the catalyst surface were analyzed through X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS) equipped with Al/Κα radiation (Thermo, ESCALAB 250XI). The obtained binding energies were referenced to the C 1s peak at 284.8 eV. 2.4 Catalytic reaction tests The epoxidation reaction was carried out in a circulating condensing system and an air oxidation environment, as presented in Fig. 1 . In a typical experiment [12], 1 g α-pinene and 120 mg Mn-SAPO-34 (catalyst) were mixed with 20 g acetonitrile (solvent) in a round-bottom glass flask, followed by addition of 0.8 g iso-butyraldehyde (co-reductant). the mixture was then reacted at 12 °C for 3 h while air was bubbled to the bottom of reactor by an air pump. The moisture in air entering the reactor was absorbed by sulfuric acid and the flow rate was controlled with an air flow valve. The solid catalyst was centrifugation after the completion of the reaction, and the liquid organic products were identified by a gas chromatograph (Agilent, 7890GC-5975MS) equipped with an HP-5 quartz capillary column (30 m × 0.25 μm × 0.32 mm), and the primary product quantitatively analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, GC-2014) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) using a DB-5 capillary column (30 m × 0.25 μm × 0.32 mm). The selectivity, yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane and the conversion of α-pinene were calculated using the following equation. (1) C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = n 0 ( α − p i n e n e ) − n t ( α − p i n e n e ) n 0 ( α − p i n e n e ) × 100 (2) S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = n ( 2 , 3 − e p o x y − p i n a n e ) n 0 ( α − p i n e n e ) − n t ( α − p i n e n e ) × 100 (3) Y i e l d ( % ) = C o n v e r s i o n × S e l e c t i v i t y × 100 2.5 Optimization of process The epoxidation reaction affecting the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane was optimized by response surface method (RSM) combined with Box-Behnken design (BBD) in Design Expert V12.0.3.0 software. Since it is impossible to determine the impact of all factors on yield, it is necessary to select factors that are sensitive to the impact of yield. First, the effect of different reaction conditions on the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane was investigated by single-factor experiments (SFE), including solvent type, solvent dosage, Mn loading amount, air flow rate, reaction temperature, reaction time, catalyst amount, and co-reductant amount. Then, sensitive conditions were screened out, and BBD was used for experimental design and data analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Single-factor experiments Since conversion and yield generally are related to reaction conditions, a single-factor experiment was performed to determine suitable conditions. Table S1 shows the effect of catalytic activity under different synthesis conditions. It can be seen that the activity of 2,3-epoxy-pinane obtained from the catalyst prepared by two-step ion-exchange is higher than that of the catalyst prepared by direct ion-exchange. In addition, the pore size and Mn content of the catalyst prepared by two-step ion-exchange are also higher than those of the catalyst prepared by direct ion-exchange method. This may be due to the small channels of the catalyst synthesized by direct ion-exchange limiting the diffusion of metal ions in the crystals. Table S2 shows the effects of various metal-SAPO-34 catalysts on the epoxidation activity of α-pinene. It can be seen that the effect of different metal-SAPO-34 catalysts on the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane was Mn-SAPO-34>Fe-SAPO-34>Co-SAPO-34>Ru-SAPO-34>Cu-SAPO-34. Among them, Mn-SAPO-34, Fe-SAPO-34 and Co-SAPO-34 showed good catalytic activity for the epoxidation of α-pinene under the present reaction condition, while Ru-SAPO-34 and Cu-SAPO-34 showed lower activity for the epoxidation of α-pinene with yields of 72.00% and 67.01%, respectively. The reason for this phenomenon may be related to the interaction of molecular oxygen with metal precursors. Of these, the metal Mn2+ appears to be the most promising catalyst, as Mn catalyst may involve high-valent manganese-oxy intermediate formed by oxo-metal IV cations. Table S3 shows the effects of various oxidants on the epoxidation of α-pinene over Mn-SAPO-34. Since the reason for choosing molecular oxygen as oxidant has been described in the introduction, we did not explain it too much here. Table S4 shows the effect of different co-reductants on the epoxidation of α-pinene over Mn-SAPO-34. It can be seen that the addition of reductants can effectively improve the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane. Among them, iso-butyraldehyde and 2-ethyl hexanol were excellent reductants in this system, and the activities of 2,3-epoxy-pinane obtained using them as reductants were both higher than 80%. However, crotonaldehyde and n-hexanal as reductants had poor catalytic effects, and the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane was 49.66% and 23.62%, respectively. Fig. 2 showed the effects of several reaction conditions on the epoxidation of α-pinene. The optimal condition of each factor was evaluated by 2,3-epoxy-pinane yield. First, the influence of the solvent and solvent dosage was studied. The reaction system with acetonitrile (20 g) as a solvent exhibited the highest catalytic activity (Fig. 2(a-b)), which may be related to the polarity of the solvent (acetonitrile possessed the highest polarity among all solvents examined). It is well known that polar solvents contribute to the desorption of polar epoxidation products and thus accelerate the renewal of the catalyst surface. As acetonitrile was incompatible with α-pinene, the formed intermediate products on catalyst surfaces are quickly transferred to solvent, avoiding excessive oxidation [28]. Then, the influence of Mn loading amount was examined (Fig. 2(c)). The yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane first increased and then decreased upon increasing the Mn loading amount. This was because proper active component Mn loading on the support was conducive to the reaction, while excessive Mn species on the support leads to the aggregation of Mn species on the catalyst surface as well as decreases its dispersion resulting in the inhibition of α-pinene conversion. Next, the influence of the air flow rate was subject of investigation (Fig. 2(d)). An increase in air flow from 30 to 80 mL/min improved the α-pinene conversion from 68.30% to 94.48% and the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane increased to 86.16%. However, the catalytic effect was not significantly changed by increasing the flow rate from 80 to 100 mL/min. This result indicated that a high oxygen level was essential for the reaction [29]. In further experiments, the dependence of catalytic activity on the reaction temperature was studied (Fig. 2(e)). With the increase in reaction temperature, the conversion and yield increased from 72.34% and 64.51% to 96.63% and 86.32%, respectively. As expected, the increase in reaction temperature could accelerate the motion of α-pinene and oxygen molecules to make them easier to contact [30]. However, the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane began to decline as the temperature was higher than 15 °C, which was attributed to the product 2,3-epoxy-pinane with ternary ring and tetra-atomic ring being more active in nature and can easily open the ring to generate other by-products, as confirmed by GC chromatograms. Next, the reaction times ranging from 0.5 to 4 h were tested (Fig. 2(f)). The analysis showed that longer reaction times were instrumental in the conversion. By increasing the reaction time from 0.5 to 2.5 h, the conversion and yield could be improved from 57.59% and 52.77% to 97.25% and 89.36%, respectively. However, the continued extension of the time from 2.5 to 4 h did not increase the conversion and slightly decreased the selectivity of 2,3-epoxy-pinane. This result was consistent with the phenomenon observed by Cao, who suggested that excessive reaction time would allow further reaction of 2,3-epoxy-pinane to form isomerization products [5]. Subsequent work concentrated on the effect of catalyst amount (Fig. 2(g)). In terms of high yield and selectivity, a catalyst amount of 100 mg was found to be favorable. This is because fewer amounts of catalysts had fewer active sites resulting in an incomplete epoxidation reaction in the system, while excessive amounts of catalysts could generate side reactions that leading to a decrease in selectivity. Finally, the amount of co-reductant used was examined (Fig. 2(h)). The experimental results showed that the addition of co-reductant (iso-butyraldehyde) can significantly improve the α-pinene conversion and 2,3-epoxy-pinane selectivity. The highest result was obtained at the co-reductant amount was 1 g. Based on the above analysis results, the suitable experimental conditions were selected as follows: 20 g acetonitrile solvent, 3 wt% Mn loading amount, 80 mL/min, 15 °C, 2.5 h, 100 mg catalyst, and 1 g co-reductant. Among them, the amount of catalyst and co-reductant, as well as Mn loading amount, have a great influence on the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane, which were sensitive conditions for the epoxidation of α-pinene. Thus, these three sensitive conditions were further optimized to obtain the best results. 3.2 Optimization of epoxidation conditions by RSM 3.2.1 Model design RSM is a common and reliable method for process optimization [31]. Thus, 2,3-epoxy-pinane synthesis was optimized via a three-level-three-factor Box-Behnken design (BBD) combined with RSM. According to the results of SFE (Section 3.1), the three levels were coded as -1, 0, and +1, and 17 runs were carried out to investigate the effect of operating parameters such as co-reductant amount (0.9-1.1 g) (X1), Mn loading amount (2.5-3.5 wt%) (X2) and catalyst amount (90-110 mg) (X3). The experimental design matrix and result were represented in Table 1 . Analysis of variance (ANOVA), coefficient of determination (R 2), residual analysis and response plots were used to analyze the results. The quadratic polynomial equation was used to predict the performance of the factors and their interaction with the production efficiency (Eq. 4). (4) Y = α 0 + ∑ i = 1 3 α i X i + ∑ i = 1 3 α i i X i 2 + ∑ i = 1 3 ∑ i < j 3 α i j X i X j + ε Where the predicted response is represented by Y, i.e. the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane; Xi and Xj are the values of independent variables; α0 is the model constant; αi, αii , and αij are the linear coefficient, quadratic coefficient and interaction coefficients, respectively; ε is the error of the model between the predicted and measured values [32]. For these experiments, a random experimental order was used to minimize errors due to latent variables. The optimization equation of yield prediction is as follows: (5) Y i e l d ( % ) = 91.914 + 2.7975 A − 1.3175 B + 1.895 C − 1.2175 A B + 0.5975 A C + 3.9475 B C − 0.24325 A 2 − 8.68825 B 2 − 3.74325 C 2 Where, A, B and C are the coded forms of co-reductant amount, Mn loading amount and catalyst amount, respectively. 3.2.2 Data analysis ANOVA is the most reliable way to evaluate the quality of the fitted model [33]. Table 2 shows the ANOVA results for the yield. The significance of each coefficient was determined by F-value and P-value. A greater F-value and smaller P-value indicated the greater model significance of the corresponding variable, where the P-value < 0.05 revealed the model was significant at the 95% confidence level [34]. In the primary item, items of A, B, C, BC, B2, and C2 were less than 0.05 suggesting that each had a significant impact on yield. Other items were not statistically significant. Regarding lack of fit, which measures the sum of squared deviations between the mean response at each factor level and the corresponding fitted value, P-value > 0.05 corresponds to insignificant response. It can be observed that the lack of fit P-value = 0.1011 > 0.05 is not significant, which indicated that the model fitted to all data (not significant lack of fit is good) [35]. A good model fit requires a coefficient of determination (R 2) of at least 0.8. Thus, the model was also evaluated based on R 2 (Table 2). The multiple correlation coefficient R 2 was 0.9776, which means that the response model can explain 97.76% of the behavior of the conversion of the α-pinene into 2,3-epoxy-pinane. And adjusted R 2 was high (Adj-R 2=0.9489), which is very close to R 2, suggesting that the levels used are consistent. Adeq precision (a measure of signal-to-noise ratio, and according to the model requirement, its value should exceed 4) was 19.9505, indicating adequate model discrimination [34]. Consequently, the above analysis confirmed that the model could be used to predict the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane from the epoxidation of α-pinene. Residual analysis was performed on the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane to further verify the applicability of the regression equation [Eq. (5)]. Fig. S1 shows residual sequence diagram of 2,3-epoxy-pinane yield. Each point in the diagram conformed to the error independence principle and had no positive and negative residual trend, which is a satisfactory model. Fig. 3 shows the predicated versus actual value 2,3-epoxy-pinane yield model. It can be observed that the predicted yield was similar to the actual yield, and the comparison points were evenly distributed on both sides of the fitted line. In addition, the residual normality of the prediction model was confirmed by the positive probability distribution plot of the residuals, which was shown in Fig. S2. Therefore, it can be concluded that the regression equation [Eq. (5)] provided a good fit to the data and could be used to predict the uninvestigated experimental variables. 3.2.3 Effect of factors and optimal conditions Response surface plots and contour line diagrams are used to select the optimal reaction conditions and understand how factors affect response variables. The response surface plots and contour lines diagram are shown in Figs. 4-6 . This is obtained by changing two factors while keeping the others remain constant. It is worth noting that the elliptical contour line suggests that the interactions between the factors were significant, while an open arc contour line indicates non-significant interactions [36]. Fig. 4 illustrates the joint effect of co-reductant and Mn loading amount on 2,3-epoxy-pinane yield. It can be observed that the contour line diagram is open arc shape, which indicates that the interaction between the co-reductant amount and Mn loading amount is non-significant (Fig. 4(b)). For constant co-reductant amount, the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane continued to increase as the Mn loading amount increased to 3.33 wt%, but beyond this value, the yield of the process decreased because moderate Mn loadings amount is beneficial to the good dispersion of active components, while excessive Mn loading amount will cause agglomeration resulting in decreases the interaction between reactants. On the other hand, at a constant Mn loading amount, the yield continued to increase with the increasing co-reductant amount. At the minimum value of the co-reductant amount and the Mn loading amount, the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane turns to its minimum value because the few co-reductant amounts do not form enough intermediates and thus the reaction is made incompletely. Fig. 5 defines the joint effect of co-reductant and catalyst on 2,3-epoxy-pinane yield. The contour line diagram is open arc shape indicating that the interaction between the two factors is non-significant, which can also be proved from variance analysis, F-value is 0.7658 and P-value is 0.4105 > 0.05. Combining Fig. 5 (a), the effect of the co-reductant amount on the yield is consistent with the previous results, which is a positive correlation. However, the effect of catalyst amount on yield is not linear. With the increase of catalyst amount, the yield first increased and then decreased. Fig. 6 shows the effect of Mn loading amount and catalyst amount on 2,3-epoxy-pinane yield. As shown in Fig. 6(b), the contour is elliptical and dense as well as steep, suggesting that the interaction between the Mn loading amount and the catalyst amount is significant. Combined with the analysis of variance, the F-value is 33.43 and the P-value is 0.0007 < 0.05, which further confirmed this conclusion. In Fig. 6(a), Similar trends to the results discussed previously can be observed concerning the effect of Mn loading amount and catalyst amount on the yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane. Based on the above analysis, it can be concluded that only the interaction of Mn loading amount and catalyst amount is significant and the predicted optimum theoretical conditions are as follows: co-reductant amount of 1.1 g, Mn loading amount of 3.33 wt%, and catalyst amount of 110 mg. The predicted yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane at this optimum condition was 90.32%. This optimization process takes into account all the interactions between different sensitive factors and their effect on the response. To verify the reliability of the model provided by RSM-BBD, the actual test conditions adopted are as follows: co-reductant amount of 1.1 g, Mn loading amount of 3.3 wt%, and catalyst amount of 110 mg. The test results revealed that the average yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane was 90.47%, with only a small relative error (0.15%) from the predicted value (Fig. S3). The similarity between the predicted and tested results confirms the good satisfaction of the model. 3.3 Reusability investigation of the catalyst One key advantage of heterogeneous catalysts is their reusability. Herein, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation, washed with ethanol, and dried at 100 °C for the next run. As shown in Fig. 7 , a minor change in 2,3-epoxy-pinane yield was observed for the first six cycles, followed by a significant decrease from 85.09% to 59.03% in the last two cycles. The results revealed that the catalyst could be reused for six runs with 85.09% efficiency. Moreover, a hot filtration experiment for α-pinene epoxidation was carried out and the result was shown in Fig. S4. As expected, no reaction precedes after the removal of the catalyst, which demonstrates that the α-pinene epoxidation was intrinsically heterogeneous. In addition, to investigate whether there is metal leaching in the reaction solution, the catalyst after six cycles was studied. According to the method described in literature [12], the solid catalyst was filtered out, and then the reaction was continued for 2 h after epoxidation reaction was conducted for 1 h. The final yields were detected by GC, and it was found that 2.13% of 2,3-epoxy-pinane was still obtained. This phenomenon may be due to the contribution of a small amount of Mn2+ ions leached from Mn-SAPO-34 and the autoxidation of α-pinene by O2, which further confirmed the characteristics of heterogeneous catalysis. 3.4 Characterization of catalyst structure Fig. 8 shows the XRD patterns of the different samples. The diffraction peak located at 9.57°, 12.98°, 14.03°, 16.12°, 20.83°, 22.13°, 25.17°, 26.15°, 28.49°, 30.87°, and 32.07°, are all assigned to SAPO-34 molecular sieve with a CHA topology (PDF#47-0429). The intensity of the diffraction peaks was greatly decreased when the Mn species was loaded into SAPO-34, probably due to the slight change of the unit cell parameters by the introduction of Mn species [37]. Mn-SAPO-34 contained regular crystal particles with a size of 1∼6 μm (Fig. S5). In Fig. 8, the diffraction peak intensity gradually decreased with the increase of the catalyst usage times, which might be due to the partial destruction of the structure of the catalyst after repeated use. This phenomenon could be proved by SEM and TEM. As shown in Fig. 9 , the crystal particles started to be destroyed when the catalyst was used 6 times, and the number of damaged crystal particles was more obvious when the catalyst was used 8 times. In addition, no characteristic peaks of MnOx were observed in the XRD patterns of the samples. This phenomenon might be due to the good dispersion of Mn species, which was confirmed by the EDS diagram of the samples (Fig. S6), It is also possible that the content of MnOx was too low to be detected by XRD [38]. Fig. 10 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the different samples. The samples showed type-IV isotherms according to the IUPAC with H4-type hysteresis loops and sharp capillary condensation steps in the range of 0.4-1.0 P/P0, demonstrating the presence of mesopores structure [39]. In addition, the isotherms revealed a sharp uptake in the region of P/P0 < 0.1, suggesting that microporous structural units were present on the surface of the SAPO-34 molecular sieves [40]. Compared with Mn-SAPO-34 (fresh), a wider hysteresis loop was observed in the isotherms of Mn-SAPO-34 (8th), which may be ascribed to more serious hysteresis caused by the blockage of the pores by excess Mn species. The textural data of the different samples were shown in Table 3 . Compared to SAPO-34 molecular sieves, the surface area and pore volume of Mn-SAPO-34 catalyst decreased slightly, indicating Mn species were successfully supported on the SAPO-34 molecular sieves' surface. The surface area and pore volume of these samples were essentially stable when the catalyst was used for the first 6 times, but that decreased obviously after 6 times, which suggested that multiple reuses of the catalyst may affect their textural properties. In addition, the Mn species content on the catalyst surface gradually decreased with the increase of catalyst usage times. It is worth noting that the Mn species content decreased slowly for the first 6 times and then decreases significantly, which was in agreement with the yields shown in Table 3. This indicated that the loss of Mn species content was one of the major reasons for catalyst deactivation. Moreover, the ratios of P, Al and Si remained constant, suggesting that the composition of the support was not affected by the reaction process. The chemical states of the surface species of the samples were investigated by XPS, as shown in Fig. 11 . For the Mn 2p, the spectrum presented two pairs of 2p3/2-2p1/2 spin-orbit split peaks, labeled as U and V, in which U′, U″, and U‴ were assigned to Mn2+, Mn3+, and Mn4+, respectively, and U⁗ represented the shake-up satellite peak of paramagnetic Mn2+ species [24,41,42]. For the O 1s, the curves contained a major peak and a shoulder peak. The major peak at 531.99 eV (labeled OⅠ) was assigned to surface oxygen species and surface hydroxide species (Os+OHs). The shoulder peak at 529.63 eV (labeled OⅡ) was assigned to lattice oxygen species (O2−) [43]. The detailed data from the spectra are presented in Table 4 . It can be observed that the molar ratio of Mn(a)/Mn(i) was 4.47, suggesting that the surface Mn species was lost during catalyst deactivation, which decreased the contact between surface Mn species and the reactants. This phenomenon was consistent with ICP analysis. Comparing the fresh catalyst and catalyst after 8 uses, the Mn2+ content decreased from 36.70% to 17.89%, the Mn3+ content increased from 9.65% to 23.12%, the Mn4+ content hardly changed and the Mn3+/Mn4+ molar ratio increased from 18.05% to 39.26%. This indicated that Mn3+ was obtained from the oxidation of Mn2+ and the reaction was irreversible, which was further confirmed by the trend of the oxygen vacancy content [44]. Therefore, it can be concluded that irreversible oxidation of Mn2+ leads to the deactivation of the catalyst. 3.5 The investigation of reaction products and mechanism To determine the epoxidation products and the epoxidation mechanism of α-pinene, eight parallel control tests were performed and the results were analyzed by GC-MS, as shown in Table 5 . When no catalyst was added to the reaction system, almost no conversion was observed. According to the GC-MS data, the major epoxidation products detected in the system without iso-butyraldehyde (IBA) were verbenol, verbenone, and 2,3-epoxy-pinane. However, when IBA was present, the main epoxidation product was 2,3-epoxy-pinane. Therefore, it can be concluded that IBA improves the selectivity of 2,3-epoxy-pinane. Other substances, such as the products of α-pinene rearrangement (oligomers and polymers) were ignored and were not listed in Table 5. In addition, we also observed that high-purity oxygen and air had the same effect on this reaction system. The conversion of α-pinene decreased sharply after the addition of benzoquinone, suggesting that radicals were involved in the reaction. Based on previous studies and the experimental results of this work, the aerobic epoxidation reaction mechanism of α-pinane on the Mn-SAPO-34 catalyst was proposed (Fig. 12 ). The mechanism was mainly carried out through the free radical pathway, and the acyl peroxy radical produced in the reaction plays the role of oxidant. RCHO (iso-butyraldehyde) preferentially forms the RC(O)● (isobutyryl) in the presence of molecular oxygen initiated by Mn2+, and then RC(O)● was oxidized by oxygen to form RC(O)-O-O• (isobutyryl peroxy radical) [7]. The subsequent introduction of α-pinene into RC(O)-O-O• to form 2,3-epoxy-pinane can be divided into two pathways. One pathway (route A) involves the reaction of RC(O)-O-O• with RCHO to form RC(O)-O-OH (peroxyisobutyric acid), followed by reacting RC(O)-O-OH with Mn2+ to form high-valent manganese-oxy intermediate. Finally, the introduction of α-pinene to produce 2,3-epoxy-pinane, which step is easily performed due to the presence of reactive high-valent metal-oxygen intermediate [11]. Another route (route B) involves the reaction of RC(O)-O-O• with α-pinene to get 2,3-epoxy-pinane directly (route B1) [5], or with Mn2+ to form manganese-peroxy complexes (route B2). Then, manganese-peroxides transfer oxygen atoms directly to α-pinene to form 2,3-epoxy-pinane and regenerate the catalytic site of Mn2+ [13]. 3.6 Comparison of Mn-SAPO-34 with literature report To further compare the results of the other catalysts used in the literature for the epoxidation of α-pinene, the relevant epoxidation data are presented in Table 6 . As can be seen from Table 6, all catalysts exhibited certain deficiencies in terms of reusability and yield. Among them, the MTO mIII and cis- [Mn(HL)2Cl2] catalyst with the highest yield are homogeneous, which is not conducive to multiple uses and requires a long reaction time. The Co-ZSM-5(L1) catalyst with the best reusable requires high temperature and tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) which is an organic oxidant and expensive. In addition, the catalytic effect of the Co-POM/NH2-SBA-15 catalyst is satisfactory, but its synthesis step is complex and requires modification of the support. In contrast to these catalysts, Mn-SAPO-34 is an environmentally friendly catalyst that is easy to prepare, achieves a high yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane under relatively mild preparation conditions and exhibited excellent stability. Moreover, the catalyst Mn-SAPO-34 was also used to catalyze the epoxidation of other olefins to extend its application, and the results are shown in Table S5. The Mn-SAPO-34 catalyst showed good catalytic activity for styrene and α-methyl styrene, but poor catalytic activity for cyclooctene and dicyclopentadiene. This may be due to the diffusion limitation of the larger cyclooctene and dicyclopentadiene molecules in small pores of SAPO-34 resulting in difficulties for the substrate to contact the active center. 4 Conclusion Mn-SAPO-34 catalyst was synthesized by an ion-exchange method and used for the epoxidation reaction of α-pinene in the presence of oxygen and iso-butyraldehyde. Single-factor experiments confirmed that Mn loading amount, catalyst and co-reductant amount were sensitive factors for this epoxidation reaction, and these sensitive factors were optimized by the response surface experiments. The results showed Mn-SAPO-34 catalyst had excellent catalytic activity. In the optimal conditions, α-pinene was completely converted and 90.47% yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane was obtained. The reusability test exhibited Mn-SAPO-34 catalyst could be effectively used 6 times without sacrificing activity and selectivity, demonstrating its recoverability and emphasizing its stability under these reaction conditions. The structural characterization experiments confirmed the reasons for the degradation of the catalyst activity were the damage of crystal particles, the decrease in specific surface area of catalyst, the loss of active components Mn and the irreversible oxidation of Mn2+. Based on the above research results, Mn-SAPO-34 catalyst with excellent activity and stability will be a very prospective catalyst for the epoxidation of α-pinene. coredata.dc:description: Aerobic epoxidation of bio-based olefins is an important topic in green and sustainable chemistry. In this work, an Mn/SAPO-34 catalyst was prepared by ion-exchange method for the epoxidation of α-pinene in presence of molecular oxygen and iso-butyraldehyde. The factors influencing α-pinene epoxidation were determined and the conditions were optimized by response surface methodology (RSM). The result showed that the sensitive conditions were co-reductant amount, Mn loading amount and catalyst amount. After optimization, α-pinene was completely converted and a 90.47% yield of 2,3-epoxy-pinane was obtained. The result showed that the catalyst was reusable for six cycles. In addition, the support and catalysts were characterized by XRD, BET, ICP-OES, SEM-EDS, TEM and XPS, and it was confirmed the reasons for the degradation of the catalyst activity were the damage of crystal particles, the decrease in specific surface area of catalyst, the loss of active components and the irreversible oxidation of Mn2+
coredata.dc:title: Aerobic epoxidation of α-pinene using Mn/SAPO-34 catalyst: Optimization via Response Surface Methodology (RSM)
